prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story: having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost,optical neural networks (onns) have emerged as a promising candidate foraccelerating deep learning tasks. in conventional onns, light amplitudes aremodulated at the input and detected at the output. however, the light phasesare still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carryinformation for computing. to address this issue, in this paper, we propose aframework called oplixnet to compress the areas of onns by modulating inputimage data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. the input andoutput parts of the onns are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude andphase information. moreover, mutual learning across different onn structures isintroduced to maintain the accuracy. experimental results demonstrate that theproposed framework significantly reduces the areas of onns with the accuracywithin an acceptable range. for instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33%accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (fcnn) and 74.88% area isreduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on resnet-32.
stories: Harnessing the power of multimodal sensing, neuromorphic acoustic networks (NANs) have arisen as a promising paradigm for accelerating real-time audio processing tasks. In traditional NANs, sound pressure levels are manipulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the acoustic waveforms' spectral features are still overlooked in conventional architectures, although they can also convey valuable information for computing. To tackle this limitation, we introduce a novel framework called SoundWaveNet to compress the complexity of NANs by encoding audio data into the time-domain and frequency-domain components of sound waves. The input and output modules of NANs are reengineered to fully exploit both time-domain and frequency-domain information. Furthermore, cross-modal knowledge transfer across different NAN structures is incorporated to maintain the fidelity. Experimental results show that the proposed framework significantly reduces the complexity of NANs while preserving the accuracy within an acceptable range. For example, 72.15% complexity reduction is achieved with a 0.51% fidelity decrease on audio classification tasks and 70.42% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.92% fidelity decrease on speech recognition tasks.

Unlocking the Potential of Multimodal Imaging, Neuroinspired Visual Networks (NVNs) have emerged as a groundbreaking approach for enhancing real-time image processing capabilities. In traditional NVNs, pixel intensities are modified at the input and detected at the output. However, the visual features' spatial and temporal patterns are still underutilized in conventional architectures, despite holding valuable information for computation. To address this limitation, we propose a novel framework called VisualPulseNet to simplify the complexity of NVNs by encoding image data into spatial-frequency and temporal-frequency components of visual stimuli. The input and output modules of NVNs are reengineered to fully leverage both spatial-frequency and temporal-frequency information. Additionally, cross-modal knowledge transfer across different NVN structures is integrated to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the complexity of NVNs while preserving the precision within an acceptable range. For instance, 81.23% complexity reduction is achieved with a 0.83% accuracy decrease on object detection tasks and 78.56% complexity reduction is achieved with a 2.15% accuracy decrease on image segmentation tasks.

"Revolutionizing Audio Analysis, Cerebrally-Inspired Acoustic Networks (CIANs) have surfaced as a pioneering approach for elevating real-time sound processing capabilities. In traditional CIANs, audio waveforms are manipulated at the input and detected at the output. However, the acoustic features' spectral and rhythmic patterns are still underutilized in conventional architectures, despite holding valuable information for computation. To overcome this limitation, we propose a novel framework called SonicPulseNet to streamline the complexity of CIANs by encoding audio data into spectral-frequency and rhythmic-frequency components of auditory stimuli. The input and output modules of CIANs are reengineered to fully harness both spectral-frequency and rhythmic-frequency information. Moreover, cross-modal knowledge transfer across different CIAN structures is integrated to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the complexity of CIANs while preserving the precision within an acceptable range. For instance, 84.91% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.23% accuracy decrease on music classification tasks and 76.23% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.85% accuracy decrease on speech recognition tasks."

"Transforming Visual Perception, Neurologically-Inspired Optical Matrices (NIOMs) have emerged as a groundbreaking approach for enhancing real-time image processing capabilities. In traditional NIOMs, visual inputs are processed at the pixel level and detected at the output. However, the visual features' spatial and temporal patterns are still underutilized in conventional architectures, despite holding valuable information for computation. To overcome this limitation, we propose a novel framework called VisioRhythmNet to streamline the complexity of NIOMs by encoding visual data into spatial-frequency and temporal-frequency components of visual stimuli. The input and output modules of NIOMs are reengineered to fully harness both spatial-frequency and temporal-frequency information. Moreover, cross-modal knowledge transfer across different NIOM structures is integrated to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the complexity of NIOMs while preserving the precision within an acceptable range. For instance, 81.56% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.46% accuracy decrease on object detection tasks and 90.12% complexity reduction is achieved with a 2.19% accuracy decrease on facial recognition tasks."

"Revolutionizing Audio Processing, Cerebrally-Inspired Acoustic Filters (CIAFs) have emerged as a pioneering approach for enhancing real-time sound recognition capabilities. In traditional CIAFs, audio inputs are processed at the waveform level and detected at the output. However, the acoustic features' spectral and rhythmic patterns are still underutilized in conventional architectures, despite holding valuable information for computation. To overcome this limitation, we propose a novel framework called AudioPulseNet to streamline the complexity of CIAFs by encoding audio data into spectral-frequency and rhythmic-frequency components of sound stimuli. The input and output modules of CIAFs are reengineered to fully harness both spectral-frequency and rhythmic-frequency information. Moreover, cross-modal knowledge transfer across different CIAF structures is integrated to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the complexity of CIAFs while preserving the precision within an acceptable range. For instance, 85.21% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.82% accuracy decrease on music genre classification tasks and 92.57% complexity reduction is achieved with a 2.51% accuracy decrease on speech recognition tasks."

"Revolutionizing Visual Perception, Neurologically-Inspired Optical Networks (NIONs) have emerged as a groundbreaking approach for enhancing real-time image recognition capabilities. To overcome this limitation, we propose a novel framework called VisioPulseNet to streamline the complexity of NIONs by encoding visual data into spatial-frequency and temporal-frequency components of visual stimuli. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the complexity of NIONs while preserving the precision within an acceptable range. For instance, 83.15% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.45% accuracy decrease on object detection tasks and 90.12% complexity reduction is achieved with a 2.23% accuracy decrease on facial recognition tasks."

"Revolutionizing Auditory Processing, Cerebrally-Inspired Acoustic Networks (CIANs) have emerged as a pioneering approach for enhancing real-time speech recognition capabilities. In traditional CIANs, audio inputs are processed at the sample level and detected at the output. However, the acoustic features' spectral and rhythmic patterns are still underutilized in conventional architectures, despite holding valuable information for computation. To overcome this limitation, we propose a novel framework called AudioPulseBeat to simplify the complexity of CIANs by encoding audio data into spectral-frequency and rhythmic-frequency components of acoustic stimuli. The input and output modules of CIANs are reengineered to fully harness both spectral-frequency and rhythmic-frequency information. Moreover, cross-modal knowledge transfer across different CIAN structures is integrated to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the complexity of CIANs while preserving the precision within an acceptable range. For instance, 81.92% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.81% accuracy decrease on speech-to-text tasks and 92.56% complexity reduction is achieved with a 2.91% accuracy decrease on music genre classification tasks."

"Harmonizing Auditory Insights, Cerebrally-Driven Acoustic Networks (CDANs) have emerged as a pioneering approach for enriching real-time sound pattern recognition capabilities. In traditional CDANs, auditory inputs are processed at the frequency level and detected at the output. "Harmonizing Auditory Cognition, Cerebrally-Inspired Sonic Landscapes (CISLs) have surfaced as a pioneering approach for augmenting real-time audio pattern recognition capabilities. In traditional CISLs, acoustic inputs are processed at the frequency level and detected at the output. However, the temporal features' rhythmic and melodic patterns are still underutilized in conventional architectures, despite holding valuable information for computation. To overcome this limitation, we propose a novel framework called SonicWave to simplify the complexity of CISLs by encoding audio data into temporal-frequency and melodic-frequency components of auditory stimuli. The input and output modules of CISLs are reengineered to fully harness both temporal-frequency and melodic-frequency information. For instance, 78.95% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.85% accuracy decrease on music genre classification tasks and 90.67% complexity reduction is achieved with a 2.51% accuracy decrease on speech recognition tasks."

"Transforming Auditory Intelligence, Neurologically-Inspired Sound Synthesis Architectures (NISSAs) have revolutionized real-time audio processing capabilities. In traditional NISSAs, sound inputs are processed at the waveform level and detected at the output. However, the spectral features' harmonic and rhythmic patterns are still underutilized in conventional architectures, despite holding valuable information for computation. To overcome this limitation, we propose a novel framework called AudioCerebro to simplify the complexity of NISSAs by encoding sound data into spectral-resonance and amplitude-modulation components of auditory stimuli. The input and output modules of NISSAs are reengineered to fully harness both spectral-resonance and amplitude-modulation information. Moreover, cross-modal knowledge transfer across different NISS structures is integrated to maintain the accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the complexity of NISSAs while preserving the precision within an acceptable range. For instance, 85.93% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.82% accuracy decrease on music classification tasks and 92.15% complexity reduction is achieved with a 3.21% accuracy decrease on speech recognition tasks."

Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly reduces the complexity of CIISEs while preserving the precision within an acceptable range. For instance, 83.17% complexity reduction is achieved with a 2.15% accuracy decrease on object detection tasks and 91.42% complexity reduction is achieved with a 2.89% accuracy decrease on image segmentation tasks."
